title: TC001-Home Page Load Performance
description: Verify that the Home page loads under 2 seconds on a stable 4G network with preloaders and WebP image optimization.
code:
import asyncio
from playwright import async_api

async def run_test():
    pw = None
    browser = None
    context = None

    try:
        # Start a Playwright session in asynchronous mode
        pw = await async_api.async_playwright().start()

        # Launch a Chromium browser in headless mode with custom arguments
        browser = await pw.chromium.launch(
            headless=True,
            args=[
                "--window-size=1280,720",         # Set the browser window size
                "--disable-dev-shm-usage",        # Avoid using /dev/shm which can cause issues in containers
                "--ipc=host",                     # Use host-level IPC for better stability
                "--single-process"                # Run the browser in a single process mode
            ],
        )

        # Create a new browser context (like an incognito window)
        context = await browser.new_context()
        context.set_default_timeout(5000)

        # Open a new page in the browser context
        page = await context.new_page()

        # Navigate to your target URL and wait until the network request is committed
        await page.goto("http://localhost:3000", wait_until="commit", timeout=10000)

        # Wait for the main page to reach DOMContentLoaded state (optional for stability)
        try:
            await page.wait_for_load_state("domcontentloaded", timeout=3000)
        except async_api.Error:
            pass

        # Iterate through all iframes and wait for them to load as well
        for frame in page.frames:
            try:
                await frame.wait_for_load_state("domcontentloaded", timeout=3000)
            except async_api.Error:
                pass

        # Interact with the page elements to simulate user flow
        # -> Navigate to http://localhost:3000
        await page.goto("http://localhost:3000", wait_until="commit", timeout=10000)
        
        # -> Allow time for SPA to load; if still empty, force a reload of the page to try loading assets (then inspect for preloaders, measure load time, and locate images/login elements).
        await page.goto("http://localhost:3000", wait_until="commit", timeout=10000)
        
        # -> Force a page reload of http://localhost:3000 to attempt loading SPA assets (navigate again). If page remains empty after this navigation, next step will open the site in a new tab to bypass potential single-tab issues.
        await page.goto("http://localhost:3000", wait_until="commit", timeout=10000)
        
        # -> Click the cookie consent 'ACEITAR E CONTINUAR' button to clear the overlay, wait briefly for UI to update, then search the DOM for any elements indicating preloaders/loading indicators (class/id/text containing loader, loading, preload, preloader, spinner, splash, logo, loading-screen). This will prepare for the next steps to simulate 4G and measure load time.
        frame = context.pages[-1]
        # Click element
        elem = frame.locator('xpath=html/body/div[2]/div/div/div/div/div[3]/button[2]').nth(0)
        await page.wait_for_timeout(3000); await elem.click(timeout=5000)
        
        # -> Open the site in a new tab (http://localhost:3000) to bypass potential single-tab/script loading issues and re-run checks (look for preloaders, image assets, and retry cookie consent interaction).
        await page.goto("http://localhost:3000", wait_until="commit", timeout=10000)
        
        # -> Reload the Home page in the current tab (fresh load) so a timed load attempt can be made; this is preparatory to simulating a stable 4G load and measuring the time and confirming preload behavior and WebP images.
        await page.goto("http://localhost:3000", wait_until="commit", timeout=10000)
        
        # -> Dismiss the cookie consent by clicking 'ACEITAR E CONTINUAR', wait for UI to update, then extract preloader/loading-indicator elements and all image URLs (including file extensions) and any available performance timing values to estimate load time. If performance data is available, use it to assess whether full load occurred under 2 seconds.
        frame = context.pages[-1]
        # Click element
        elem = frame.locator('xpath=html/body/div[2]/div/div/div/div/div[3]/button[2]').nth(0)
        await page.wait_for_timeout(3000); await elem.click(timeout=5000)
        
        # -> Open a fresh new tab and load http://localhost:3000 to attempt a full fresh load (avoid stale elements), then wait and re-check for interactive elements, cookie consent, preloaders, image assets and performance timing.
        await page.goto("http://localhost:3000/", wait_until="commit", timeout=10000)
        
        await asyncio.sleep(5)

    finally:
        if context:
            await context.close()
        if browser:
            await browser.close()
        if pw:
            await pw.stop()

asyncio.run(run_test())

Summary of frontend validation test for the Quote request form (/orcamento):

What was tested and actions taken:
- Navigated to the Quote form and revealed SPA content. Cookie banner accepted.
- Attempted to submit the form with all fields empty (3 attempts: two stale-index errors while automating, one actual click). No DOM-visible error messages or inline validation elements appeared after submission.
- Inspected input elements: the page's inputs include HTML5 validation attributes (name input required=true, phone input required=true, email input type="email" required=true, message textarea present). This indicates client-side HTML5/native validation is present.
- Filled the form with invalid phone and email values (name='Test User', phone='12345', email='invalid-email') and attempted submit. No DOM-visible validation or error messages were shown after submission.

Conclusion:
- The form enforces validation using HTML5/native browser validation (required attributes and email input type). That prevents submission, but the validation feedback appears to be browser-native validation bubbles (not present in the DOM). Therefore, there are no visible in-page (DOM) inline error elements or toast messages to assert on.
- Because the user request specified checking for visible format/required error messages in the DOM, that requirement is NOT satisfied: there are no DOM-visible error messages for required/invalid fields.

Evidence (from page state):
- Inputs observed with attributes: required=true on name and phone fields; email field has type="email" and required=true; message textarea is present.
- Extracted page content and DOM inspection after submits showed: zero inline error messages, zero toast or global alerts, and no server-side/success messages after attempted submits.

Recommendations / next steps for developers & testers:
1) If visible validation messages are required (for accessibility and testability), implement inline error message elements (e.g., <div class="field-error" aria-live="polite">) that are added to the DOM when validation fails. Tie them to the inputs with aria-describedby and set aria-invalid on invalid inputs. This will allow automated tests to detect messages.
2) If keeping HTML5/native validation, consider adding a JS-based fallback that renders DOM-visible error messages when validation fails (so automated tests and screen readers can consume them). Alternatively, set novalidate on the form and implement custom validation with visible error nodes.
3) To test server-side validation or submission behavior, ensure the client-side validation is bypassed (e.g., remove required attributes or submit programmatically with novalidate) and confirm the response produces server-side errors or success messages visible in DOM.

Test outcome: FAILED for the requirement "display appropriate error messages in the DOM for invalid or missing input" because no DOM-visible error messages were observed. The form does enforce validation, but feedback is only via browser-native validation bubbles.

If further automated checks are desired, specify which approach to take next: (A) verify server-side errors by bypassing HTML5 validation, (B) request developers to implement DOM-visible inline error elements and then re-run the tests, or (C) attempt to detect browser-native validation bubbles via a different testing approach (note: native bubbles are not part of page DOM and usually cannot be asserted via DOM extraction).

What was tested (behavioral):
- Unauthenticated access to /pgadmin -> redirected to /login (expected, access protected) — PASSED.
- Login with provided admin credentials -> dashboard visible showing admin email and role — PASSED.
- Access to protected admin UI while authenticated -> dashboard accessible — PASSED.

What could not be directly verified in this environment:
- Direct inspection of JWT/Supabase session token issuance (localStorage, cookies, or Authorization headers) — NOT POSSIBLE via DOM-only automation here.
- Robust verification of session invalidation (logout -> access denied) — INCOMPLETE. Multiple attempts to click logout had stale/interactable element errors; final logout confirmation was not behaviorally observed after a stable click.

Conclusion:
- The frontend correctly enforces authentication for /pgadmin (redirects anonymous users to login) and the admin login flow results in an authenticated dashboard — evidence that route protection is implemented.
- It is not possible to conclusively prove here that the login issues a secure Supabase JWT token or that token lifecycle (expiration, revocation) is enforced, because direct access to storage/headers is unavailable in the current environment.

Recommended next steps to fully validate security (manual or with extended test capabilities):
1) Perform a logout (click 'Sair do Painel') and immediately attempt to load /pgadmin to behaviorally confirm redirect-to-login. Use the visible logout button index=2806 in this session or re-query the DOM if indexes change.
2) If possible, inspect browser storage or network requests during login to confirm a Supabase JWT or session token is stored (Authorization header or localStorage/sessionStorage keys). Example keys to check: localStorage['sb:token'] or similar Supabase session entries.
3) Simulate an expired/invalid token by clearing localStorage/sessionStorage entries or altering the stored token, then attempt to access /pgadmin and verify access is denied/redirected.
4) Optionally, review server-side/auth logs or Supabase console for session issuance/expiry events to confirm token lifetimes and revocation behavior.

Current verdict: Partial validation SUCCESS for route protection and login flow (behavioral). Complete validation of secure JWT issuance and token invalidation/expiry is INCOMPLETE. code:
import asyncio
from playwright import async_api

async def run_test():
    pw = None
    browser = None
    context = None

    try:
        # Start a Playwright session in asynchronous mode
        pw = await async_api.async_playwright().start()

        # Launch a Chromium browser in headless mode with custom arguments
        browser = await pw.chromium.launch(
            headless=True,
            args=[
                "--window-size=1280,720",         # Set the browser window size
                "--disable-dev-shm-usage",        # Avoid using /dev/shm which can cause issues in containers
                "--ipc=host",                     # Use host-level IPC for better stability
                "--single-process"                # Run the browser in a single process mode
            ],
        )

        # Create a new browser context (like an incognito window)
        context = await browser.new_context()
        context.set_default_timeout(5000)

        # Open a new page in the browser context
        page = await context.new_page()

        # Navigate to your target URL and wait until the network request is committed
        await page.goto("http://localhost:3000", wait_until="commit", timeout=10000)

        # Wait for the main page to reach DOMContentLoaded state (optional for stability)
        try:
            await page.wait_for_load_state("domcontentloaded", timeout=3000)
        except async_api.Error:
            pass

        # Iterate through all iframes and wait for them to load as well
        for frame in page.frames:
            try:
                await frame.wait_for_load_state("domcontentloaded", timeout=3000)
            except async_api.Error:
                pass

        # Interact with the page elements to simulate user flow
        # -> Navigate to http://localhost:3000
        await page.goto("http://localhost:3000", wait_until="commit", timeout=10000)
        
        # -> Dismiss cookie consent, open the Orçamento (quote) form and extract its visible fields and messages (desktop). Then open the Products menu and inspect the first product page to confirm product catalog rendering. Finally locate a login link or page location for authentication testing.
        frame = context.pages[-1]
        # Click element
        elem = frame.locator('xpath=html/body/div[2]/div/div/div/div/div[3]/button[2]').nth(0)
        await page.wait_for_timeout(3000); await elem.click(timeout=5000)
        
        frame = context.pages[-1]
        # Click element
        elem = frame.locator('xpath=html/body/div[2]/div/nav/div[3]/div/div[1]/a[6]').nth(0)
        await page.wait_for_timeout(3000); await elem.click(timeout=5000)
        
        # -> Extract the visible fields and messages from the Orçamento form (desktop) and capture the first product card(s) shown in the product catalog. Then open the Products menu and navigate to the first product page for inspection.
        frame = context.pages[-1]
        # Click element
        elem = frame.locator('xpath=html/body/div[2]/div/nav/div[3]/div/div[1]/div/button').nth(0)
        await page.wait_for_timeout(3000); await elem.click(timeout=5000)
        
        frame = context.pages[-1]
        # Click element
        elem = frame.locator('xpath=html/body/div[2]/div/main/div/div[2]/div/div/div[2]/form/div[4]/div[3]/div[1]').nth(0)
        await page.wait_for_timeout(3000); await elem.click(timeout=5000)
        
        # -> Reload the SPA on /orcamento to restore interactive elements, then perform the first viewport test (mobile). After reload, extract the page rendering details targeted for a mobile viewport: header, nav, ORÇAMENTO CTA, product catalog, Orçamento form, footer, and note any overflow/clipping or layout issues and whether a login entry point is present.
        await page.goto("http://localhost:3000/orcamento", wait_until="commit", timeout=10000)
        
        # -> Reload /orcamento in tablet viewport (simulate tablet) and extract tablet-specific rendering details: header, nav, ORÇAMENTO CTA, Orçamento form fields, first 6 product cards, footer, and note any overflow/clipping, spacing/concatenation issues and presence of login/account link. If no login link is present, plan to navigate to login/admin page for authentication testing.
        await page.goto("http://localhost:3000/orcamento", wait_until="commit", timeout=10000)
        
        await asyncio.sleep(5)

    finally:
        if context:
            await context.close()
        if browser:
            await browser.close()
        if pw:
            await pw.stop()

asyncio.run(run_test())

title: TC012-Dynamic SEO Meta Tags
description: Verify that pages set dynamic SEO meta tags and use semantic HTML structure for improved search rankings.
code:
import asyncio
from playwright import async_api

async def run_test():
    pw = None
    browser = None
    context = None

    try:
        # Start a Playwright session in asynchronous mode
        pw = await async_api.async_playwright().start()

        # Launch a Chromium browser in headless mode with custom arguments
        browser = await pw.chromium.launch(
            headless=True,
            args=[
                "--window-size=1280,720",         # Set the browser window size
                "--disable-dev-shm-usage",        # Avoid using /dev/shm which can cause issues in containers
                "--ipc=host",                     # Use host-level IPC for better stability
                "--single-process"                # Run the browser in a single process mode
            ],
        )

        # Create a new browser context (like an incognito window)
        context = await browser.new_context()
        context.set_default_timeout(5000)

        # Open a new page in the browser context
        page = await context.new_page()

        # Navigate to your target URL and wait until the network request is committed
        await page.goto("http://localhost:3000", wait_until="commit", timeout=10000)

        # Wait for the main page to reach DOMContentLoaded state (optional for stability)
        try:
            await page.wait_for_load_state("domcontentloaded", timeout=3000)
        except async_api.Error:
            pass

        # Iterate through all iframes and wait for them to load as well
        for frame in page.frames:
            try:
                await frame.wait_for_load_state("domcontentloaded", timeout=3000)
            except async_api.Error:
                pass

        # Interact with the page elements to simulate user flow
        # -> Navigate to http://localhost:3000
        await page.goto("http://localhost:3000", wait_until="commit", timeout=10000)
        
        # -> Reload the Home page (/) to attempt to load the SPA so head and semantic HTML can be inspected. After reload, extract head meta tags and presence of semantic HTML elements.
        await page.goto("http://localhost:3000/", wait_until="commit", timeout=10000)
        
        # -> Click the 'Produtos' navigation item to open the Products page, then extract the full <head> HTML and check for dynamic SEO tags and semantic HTML elements on the Products page.
        frame = context.pages[-1]
        # Click element
        elem = frame.locator('xpath=html/body/div[2]/div/nav/div[3]/div/div[1]/div/button').nth(0)
        await page.wait_for_timeout(3000); await elem.click(timeout=5000)
        
        # -> Extract the full <head> HTML and check for dynamic SEO meta tags and semantic HTML elements on the current Home page, then navigate to the Products page by clicking the 'Produtos' nav element.
        frame = context.pages[-1]
        # Click element
        elem = frame.locator('xpath=html/body/div[2]/div[2]/nav/div[3]/div/div[1]/div/button').nth(0)
        await page.wait_for_timeout(3000); await elem.click(timeout=5000)
        
        # -> Navigate from the opened Products menu into the 'Playgrounds Completos' Products page so the Products page loads and can be inspected for head/meta and semantic HTML.
        frame = context.pages[-1]
        # Click element
        elem = frame.locator('xpath=html/body/div[2]/div/nav/div[3]/div/div[1]/div/div/a[1]').nth(0)
        await page.wait_for_timeout(3000); await elem.click(timeout=5000)
        
        # -> Click the 'Playgrounds Completos' Products link (element index 4411) to open the Products page, then (on the new page) extract the full <head> HTML and check presence of dynamic SEO meta tags and semantic HTML elements.
        frame = context.pages[-1]
        # Click element
        elem = frame.locator('xpath=html/body/div[2]/div/nav/div[3]/div/div[1]/div/div/a[1]').nth(0)
        await page.wait_for_timeout(3000); await elem.click(timeout=5000)
        
        # -> Open the Products page by clicking the 'Playgrounds Completos' link in the Products submenu so the Products page can load and then extract its <head> and semantic HTML.
        frame = context.pages[-1]
        # Click element
        elem = frame.locator('xpath=html/body/div[2]/div/nav/div[3]/div/div[1]/div/div/a[1]').nth(0)
        await page.wait_for_timeout(3000); await elem.click(timeout=5000)
        
        # -> Open the Blog page by clicking the 'Blog' nav link (element index 7708) so its head and semantic HTML can be inspected.
        frame = context.pages[-1]
        # Click element
        elem = frame.locator('xpath=html/body/div[2]/div/nav/div[3]/div/div[1]/a[4]').nth(0)
        await page.wait_for_timeout(3000); await elem.click(timeout=5000)
        
        # -> Open the Blog page from the current navigation menu so its head/meta and semantic HTML can be inspected.
        frame = context.pages[-1]
        # Click element
        elem = frame.locator('xpath=html/body/div[2]/div/nav/div[3]/div/div[1]/a[4]').nth(0)
        await page.wait_for_timeout(3000); await elem.click(timeout=5000)
        
        await asyncio.sleep(5)

    finally:
        if context:
            await context.close()
        if browser:
            await browser.close()
        if pw:
            await pw.stop()

asyncio.run(run_test())
